frame.name: Level_of_force_resistance
frame.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> is capable of resisting or does resist a physical <fen>Opposing_force</fen> to a level specified by the target. With certain LUs (e.g. <m>impregnable.a</m>), the <fen>Opposing_force</fen> FE is incorporated, and with many LUs, it is mostly null instantiated. This frame covers both individual-level/static uses ("the DURABILITY of jade") as well as stage-level/dynamic uses ("the shoulder is PLIABLE after stretching"), although the individual-level meaning is the more basic and is much more prominent in the data.
<ex>The great and <t>impregnable</t> <fex name="Ent">fortress</fex> still stands today.</ex>
<ex><fex name="Ent">His heart</fex> is <fex name="Degree">by no means</fex> <t>strong</t>, so he should ease into his exercise regime. <fex name="Opp">INI</fex></ex>
<ex>They were strapping athletic lads with fine belts and <t>sturdy</t> <fex name="Ent">boots</fex>. <fex name="Opp">INI</fex></ex>
<ex><fex name="Ent">The staircase</fex> <m>remained</m> <t>robust</t> <fex name="Opp">under decades of heavy use</fex>.</ex>
Productive metaphors include cases where the social resistance of an entity to (an) opposing social force(s) is conceptualized as the physical resistance of an entity to an opposing physical force. More specifically, the ‘resistance’ is an entity’s propensity to resist change in social realms such as the economic, political, and cultural: <ex>California has had (until now) a <t>robust</t> <fex name="Ent">property market</fex>. <fex name="Opp">INI</fex></ex> <ex>The <t>durability</t> <fex name="Ent">of the peace</fex> will soon be tested. <fex name="Opp">INI</fex></ex>
Similarly, there are instances where the entity’s resistance is psychological instead of social, where ‘psychological’ subsumes emotional and other mental properties: <ex><fex name="Ent">The idea</fex> <m>proved</m> <fex name="Desc">remarkably</fex> <t>durable</t>.</ex> <ex>We should remember the <t>fragility</t> <fex name="Ent">of the human psyche</fex>. <fex name="Opp">INI</fex></ex> <ex>His <t>sturdy</t> <fex name="Ent">resilience</fex> to knocks and setbacks was impressive. <fex name="Opp">INI</fex></ex>
<ex></ex>
Compare to: Level_of_force_exertion. </def-root>

FE.name: Resisting_entity
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> is the item that resists the <fen>Opposing_force</fen> to the level specified by the target.
<ex>These are made from a <t>tough</t> <fex name="Ent">plastic foam</fex> and are very light to wear.</ex>
<ex>A great number of <t>hardy</t> <fex name="Ent">plants</fex> usually succeed in blooming even in the severest season.</ex>
<ex>The <t>fragile</t> <fex name="Ent">canoe</fex> did not capsize!</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Degree
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Degree</fen> to which the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> resists.
<ex>Their colonial structures turned out to be <fex name="Deg">very</fex> <t>durable</t>.</ex>
Where <fen>Degree</fen> is expressed by a comparative or superlative form of the target, the FE is marked on the target (as well as on the rest of the comparative/superlative expression, if present): <ex>On the whole, triticale is <t><fex name="Deg">hardier</fex></t> <fex name="Deg">than wheat</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Place
FE.definition:
<def-root>The location where the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> resists an external force.
<ex>They decided the tree-house would be <t>sturdiest</t> <fex name="Pla">in the big old backyard oak</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Time
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> resists an external force.
<ex>The retaining wall was even <t>weaker</t> <fex name="Tim">yesterday</fex>, and had begun to crumble.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Circumstances
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Circumstances</fen> under which the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> resists an external force.
<ex>Wexford thought the yellow chair felt <t>flimsy</t> <fex name="Cir">as he lowered his heavy body into it</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Descriptor
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE describes the force resistance of the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen>.
<ex>Scottish ancestors had given her an <fex name="Desc">amazing</fex> <t>toughness</t> which enabled her to endure the hardships of life.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Domain
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Domain</fen> is the field in which the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> resists an external force.
<ex>Factors that determine the choice of materials include <fex name="Dom">physical</fex> <t>robustness</t>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Opposing_force
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Opposing_force</fen> is the item placed in opposition to the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen>. <fen>Opposing_force</fen> hinders, blocks, helps, or allows (lets) the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> to resist at the level specified by the target. Sometimes this Core FE is incorporated in the target; otherwise, it is often null instantiated in example sentences.
<ex>The fortress was <t>impregnable</t> <fex name="Opp">to attack by hostile invaders</fex>.</ex>
<ex>Its best-known feature is its soft and <t>pliable</t> duck-like beak. <fex name="Opp">INI</fex> </ex> </def-root>

lexUnit.name: duurzaamheid.n
lexUnit.definition: waarin iets werkt zoals het hoort
